content.text: CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) is a global dictionary of publicly known cybersecurity vulnerabilities, each assigned a unique identifier (e.g., CVE-2024-12345). It is maintained by MITRE Corporation and serves as a standardized way to reference security vulnerabilities across the cybersecurity community.
A CVE identifier has three parts: CVE-YYYY-NNNNN

items: CVE: Indicates it's a vulnerability record
YYYY: Year the vulnerability was discovered or assigned
NNNNN: Unique ID number for that year (sequential number)

content.text: Each CVE has a severity score (CVSS - Common Vulnerability Scoring System) from 0.0 to 10.0, indicating how critical the vulnerability is:

items: 0.1 - 3.9 (Low): Low risk, should be addressed but not urgent
4.0 - 6.9 (Medium): Moderate risk, should be patched soon
7.0 - 8.9 (High): High risk, should be patched immediately
9.0 - 10.0 (Critical): Most severe, requires urgent action and immediate patching

content.text: VaultGuard Pro detects your technology stack (e.g., WordPress version, PHP version, JavaScript libraries, frameworks) and cross-references them with live CVE databases using Google Search Grounding. This allows real-time detection of known vulnerabilities in the specific versions you're using.

content.title: CVE.org (Official List)
content.text: The official source for all CVE identifiers. This is where all CVE numbers are registered and maintained. Website: https://www.cve.org/

content.title: NVD (National Vulnerability Database)
content.text: Maintained by NIST, provides detailed information about each CVE including CVSS scores, affected products, and remediation guidance. Website: https://nvd.nist.gov/

content.title: CVE Details
content.text: User-friendly interface for searching CVEs by vendor, product, or vulnerability type. Makes it easier to find relevant CVEs for specific technologies. Website: https://www.cvedetails.com/

Knowing which CVEs affect your technology stack helps you prioritize security updates. Critical and High severity CVEs should be patched immediately, while Medium and Low severity ones can be scheduled for regular maintenance windows.

items: Regularly check for CVEs affecting your technology stack
Prioritize Critical and High severity CVEs for immediate patching
Subscribe to security advisories for technologies you use
Keep all dependencies and components up to date
Use automated tools (like VaultGuard Pro) to detect CVEs
Maintain an inventory of all software components and versions
